subject: Drop become in stackhpc.libvirt-vm for seed vm provision
commit_message:
Drop become in stackhpc.libvirt-vm for seed vm provision

Prior to this change, the seed VM was provisioned using the
stackhpc.livirt-vm role with become=true. This resulted in the cached
image being owned by root. The infra VM provisioning uses
stackhpc.libvirt-vm without become=true. If an infra VM uses the same
image as the seed, this can lead to permission denied errors when
downloading a new image of the same name.

This change adds a workaround to fix up the ownership of the cached
image during infra VM provisioning to avoid this issue.

This change also drops become=true from stackhpc.libvirt-vm during seed
VM provisioning, and adds the same workaround there.

subject: Use "resolvectl dns" to retrieve the DNS nameservers
commit_message:
Use "resolvectl dns" to retrieve the DNS nameservers

If "resolvectl" [1] is present in the VM image (not in Cirros but in
other advance images), the test retrieves the DNS nameservers from
the output of this command.

Output example:
  root@ubuntu:~# resolvectl dns
  Global: 3.3.4.4 3.3.3.3
  Link 2 (ens3): 10.20.0.2 10.20.0.3
  Link 3 (enp0s31f6):

The nameservers will be located under "Global" or in the corresponding
interface depending on the resolvectl configuration.

The new implemented method, "_resolvectl_dns", will create a set of
nameservers per interface (on those ones with a non empty list).
The method will return a list of sets; e.g.:
  [{"3.3.4.4", "3.3.3.3"}, {"10.20.0.2", "10.20.0.3"}]

The test case check this list of sets of nameservers with the expected
set. If the expected set of nameservers match with any of them, the
assertion is validated.

[1]https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/resolvectl.1.html

Closes-Bug: #1929523

subject: go: middleware to allow creating test objects
commit_message:
go: middleware to allow creating test objects

FakeObject is a http middleware allowing fast creation of large objects
without needing to transfer data over the netwrok.  To use it you must
set the 'Content-Length' to 0 and 'X-Backend-Fake-Body' headers, where
X-Backend-Fake-Body is the size in bytes you want your object created
with.

The primary use for this is to be able to test replication speeds by
being able to create a lot of objects, large and small, in a very
short period of time, skipping the network transfer time that would
normaly be needed.

To use, send a HTTP PUT directly to the storage node with
the X-Backend-Fake-Body header, and a Content-Length of 0.

For example, the following will create a 4GB object:
$ curl -i -XPUT http://127.0.0.1:6010/sdb6/947/AUTH_test/c/o \
-H'Content-Length: 0' \
-H'Content-Type: multipart/form-data' \
-H'X-Timestamp: 1462382174.25588' \
-H'X-Backend-Fake-Body: 4000000000'
HTTP/1.1 201 Created
Content-Length: 0
Content-Type: text/html
Etag: d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e
Date: Wed, 04 May 2016 21:00:59 GMT

The created object will be tagged with
'X-Object-Sysmeta-Fake-Body: true' to make it easier to identify
objects created this way.

$ curl -I -XHEAD http://127.0.0.1:6010/sdb6/947/AUTH_test/c/o
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Accept-Ranges: bytes
Content-Length: 4000000000
Content-Type: multipart/form-data
Etag: "d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e"
Last-Modified: Wed, 04 May 2016 17:16:15 GMT
X-Backend-Timestamp: 1462382174.25588
X-Object-Sysmeta-Fake-Body: true
X-Timestamp: 1462382174.25588
Date: Wed, 04 May 2016 21:01:18 GMT

Change-Id: I0eb09fc7214e70feba1c09b22a0323ea43be07d9

subject: go: fix improper request cancellation
commit_message:
go: fix improper request cancellation

Currently cancel channel is shared  by all the requests in firstResponse
method and closed when the method returns. That means all the
requests will be marked as cancelled including the successful one. Thus
the underlying tcp connections will be canncelled in both directions.
However, at that time, the body of the successful request is not
necessarily drained. This race will occur when the object is large
enough. It occurs every time when the object is larger than 100KB in my
cluster and causes the end users get incomplete response body.

The race can be solved by getting rid of the canncel channel.
But that will cause tcp connection leak between the proxy server and
object server in heavy load scenario.

This patch leverages the new Context mechanism introduced since Go 1.7
instead of the deprecated Request.Cancel channel mechanism.

Change-Id: I847179dd7a56ab428459fa34153214641d314291

subject: [WIP] Fix LCM failure
commit_message:
[WIP] Fix LCM failure

In current implementation, if the tacker servers go down during LCM
operation, the operation state will be fixed to `PROCESSING` even after
servers restart. Once this problem happens, users cannot chagne the
operation state with APIs, which means users have to change the state by
updating DB directly.

This patch fix this problem by changing the state of LCM operations in
`PROCESSING` to `FAILED_TEMP` when the servers restart. As restarting
can be triggered for other reasons than server down issues, only the
state that is in `PROCESSING` beyond the predefined timeout are changed.
Note that, in order to realize the above, the server saves `error_point`
every time it is updated instead of saving it in memory.

In addition, this patch includes the following minor fixes and
refactoring:

- Reformatted args in UT
- Removed redundant `_scale_vnf` method as this method does nothing
- Removed `vnf_instance` and `vnf_lcm_op_occ` from the arguments of
`_update_vnf_scaling` method as these are updated without using this
method in many places
- Moved the definition of status constants from `conductor_server.py` to
`constants.py`
- Explicitly imported the Vim model for the VNF model as Vim model must
be imported before `tacker/db/vnfm/vnfm_db.py` [1], otherwise
`InvalidRequestError` will occur

[1] https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/orm/basic_relationships.html#late-evaluation-of-relationship-arguments

Change-Id: Id3d60db9498884b0d64f2d96028201c1f3cf2fff

Sphinx installs the package with its dependencies, but it does not use
the constraints. This can lead to errors if a dependency introduces any
backward incompatible changes. To avoid this the dependencies needs to
be installed prior to sphinx run by tox with the correct constraints.

  the lower-constraints job pass (with the new pip dependency resolver,

  - alembic 0.9.6 is required for oslo.db 6.0.0

commit_message:
Delete log entries when SG or port is deleted

NOTE: this patch is an ammend of [1].

When a SG or a port is deleted, the related log entry should be
too. A log entry has the following fields:
- log.resource_id = SG ID
- log.target_id = port ID

[1] was deleting all log entries, related or not with the SG ID
deleted. This is because "get_logs_bound_sg" returned all log entries,
including those ones without any "resource_id" or "target_id".

Now this method can return only the log entries related to a port or
a SG, excluding those ones without those two parameters populated.

subject: WIP tentative known hosts forcing for remotes
commit_message:
WIP tentative known hosts forcing for remotes

When we upgrade from Centos7 to Centos8 we switch authentication
mechanism for remotes (from pcs resource create remote.. to pcs host
auth + pcs cluster node add-remote). During FFU special care is done
to leave the non upgraded remotes alone, but this causes us to have the
remotes show up in pcs status but not being registered in pcsd's
/var/lib/pcsd/known-hosts.

In order to make sure, let's consider a remote non existing
if it is not registered in pcs' known-hosts file but also we need to
make sure to call pcs cluster node add-remote *only* when
the pcs remote does not exist.

Tested as follows:
1. On an existing train setup with remotes:
[root@controller-0 tripleo-config]# pcs status |grep compute
  * compute-0   (ocf::pacemaker:remote):         Started controller-0
  * compute-1   (ocf::pacemaker:remote):         Started controller-1

2. Removed compute-0 from known-hosts in /var/lib/pcsd/known-hosts
3. Rerun puppet and obtained the following:
Debug: Remote resource_exists: resource compute-0 is in known_hosts: false
Debug: Exists: resource compute-0 exists 1 resource deep_compare: false
Debug: backup_cib: pcs cluster cib /var/lib/pacemaker/cib/puppet-cib-backup20211019-954815-1ezmiuk returned
Debug: try 1/5: pcs -f /var/lib/pacemaker/cib/puppet-cib-backup20211019-954815-1ezmiuk resource config compute-0 > /dev/null 2>&1
Debug: try 1/5: pcs host auth compute-0 addr=172.17.1.127 -u hacluster -p "VCgCGgkxdLmINPot"

4. Observed the remote still in a cluster and present in known-hosts:
[root@controller-0 tripleo-config]# grep compute-0 /var/lib/pcsd/known-hosts
    "compute-0": {
[root@controller-0 tripleo-config]# pcs status |grep -e 'compute-0.*remote'
  * compute-0   (ocf::pacemaker:remote):         Started controller-0

subject: Prevent leaked greenlets to interact with later tests
commit_message:
Prevent leaked greenlets to interact with later tests

In out functional tests we run nova services as greenlets. Also those
services can spawn there own greenlets for RPC or other parallel
processing. The test case executor only sees and tracks the main
greenlet where the code of the test case is running. When that is
finishes the test executor considers the test case to be finished
regardless of the other spawned greenlets. This could lead to leaked
greenlets that are running in parallel with later test cases.

One way that it can cause trouble is via the global variables in
nova.rpc module. Those globals are re-initialized for each test case so
they are not directly leaking information between test cases. However if
a late greenlet calls nova.rpc.get_versioned_notifier() it will get a
totally usable FakeVersionedNotifier object regardless of which test
case this notifier is belongs to or which test case the greenlet belongs
to. This way the late greenelt can send a notification to the currently
running test case and therefore can make it fail.

The current case we saw is the following:

1) The test case
  nova.tests.functional.test_servers.ServersTestV219.test_description_errors
  creates a server but don't wait for it to reach terminal state (ACTIVE
  / ERROR). This test case finishes quickly but leaks running greenlets
  in the background waiting for some RPC call to return.
2) As the test case finished the cleanup code deletes the test case
   specific setup, including the DB.
3) The test executor moves forward and starts running another test case
4) 60 seconds later the leaked greenlet times out waiting for the RPC
   call to return and tries doing things, but fails as the DB is already
   gone. Then it tries to  report this as an error notification. It calls
   nova.rpc.get_versioned_notifier() and gets a fresh notifier that is
   connected to the currently running test case. Then emits the error
   notification there.
5) The currently running test case also waits for an error notification
   to be triggered by the currently running test code. But it gets the
   notification form the late greenlet first. As the content of the
   notification does not match with the expectations the currently
   running test case fails. The late greenlet prints a lot of
   error about the DB being gone making the troubleshooting pretty hard.

This patch proposes a way to kill every leaking greenlets at the end of
each test case.

Change-Id: If5a0f2daace83cb85030cb3e253608a90f733ce4

subject: Use Nehalem CPU model by default
commit_message:
Use Nehalem CPU model by default

CentOS/RHEL 9 are being compiled for the x86_64-v2 architecture which is
newer than the qemu default of qemu64. This means that for devstack to
boot these instances we need a newer CPU model. Nehalem is apparently
the oldest model that works for x86_64-v2 and is expected to work on
Intel and AMD cpus with kvm or qemu. Switch devstack to this model by
default.

Note that we cannot use host-passthrough or host-model because we want
to support live migration between devstack deployed nova-compute
instances and even within the CI instances that we get the host CPUs can
differ.

Also, we should run this change against as many clouds as possible to
ensure that the newer model works across all of our clouds. There is
some fear that the virtual CPUs presented to us in some clouds may not
be able to run these newer CPU models.

subject: [ovn] Stop monitoring the SB MAC_Binding table to reduce mem footprint
commit_message:
[ovn] Stop monitoring the SB MAC_Binding table to reduce mem footprint

The MAC_Binding table in the SB database may grow indefinitely (due
to a lack of an aging mechanism of its entries) and eventually
lead to OOM killers for neutron-server which maintains an in-memory
copy of the database.

In order to stop monitoring this table, this patch is invoking
the ovsdb-client tool to remove the entries associated to
Floating IPs that have just been detached. The execution of this
tool is really fast as it will just invoke a JSON-RPC transact command
which doesn't require downloading the database contents.

In a scale test, the memory consumption of neutron-server dropped
from 75GB to 7GB with this patch.

Closes-Bug: #1946318

  neutron/tests/functional/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/test_ovsdb_monitor.py

subject: [WIP] Fix LCM failure
commit_message:
[WIP] Fix LCM failure

In current implementation, if the tacker servers go down during LCM
operation, the operation state will be fixed to `PROCESSING` even after
servers restart. Once this problem happens, users cannot chagne the
operation state with APIs, which means users have to change the state by
updating DB directly.

This patch fix this problem by changing the state of LCM operations in
`PROCESSING` to `FAILED_TEMP` when the servers restart. As restarting
can be triggered for other reasons than server down issues, only the
state that is in `PROCESSING` beyond the predefined timeout are changed.
Note that, in order to realize the above, the server saves `error_point`
every time it is updated instead of saving it in memory.

In addition, this patch includes the following minor fixes and
refactoring:

- Reformatted args in UT
- Removed redundant `_scale_vnf` method as this method does nothing
- Removed `vnf_instance` and `vnf_lcm_op_occ` from the arguments of
`_update_vnf_scaling` method as these are updated without using this
method in many places
- Moved the definition of status constants from `conductor_server.py` to
`constants.py`
- Explicitly imported the Vim model for the VNF model as Vim model must
be imported before `tacker/db/vnfm/vnfm_db.py` [1], otherwise
`InvalidRequestError` will occur

[1] https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/orm/basic_relationships.html#late-evaluation-of-relationship-arguments

Change-Id: I632460b31fc46b0cfb20b9529493c88625db14f0
